author: By Joshua M. Sharfstein and Melissa A. Marx
title: Testing is Just the Beginning in the Battle Against Covid-19
description: We need a comprehensive strategy to prevent the spread of the disease.
content: As the United States scrambles to expand testing for coronavirus infections, the nation’s capacity for putting into place what should follow a positive result — isolating the infected and quarantining their contacts — is profoundly limited. Yet these two steps are essential for controlling the spread of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Joe Diffie, Grammy-Winning Country Music Star, Dies at 61
description: He was known for his ballads and honky-tonk singles, like “Home” and “Pickup Man.” On Friday, he announced that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Joe Diffie, a country singer who had a string of hits in the 1990s with chart-topping ballads and honky-tonk singles like “Home” and “Pickup Man,” died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: Predators and Prey
description: Dolores is learning that we humans have our redeeming moments. Caleb learns that humans and Dolores aren’t so different.
content: Much of the first two seasons of “Westworld” was about the hosts wresting control of their destinies and exercising the same freedoms enjoyed by their human tormentors, who had cast them as attractions in a sadistic Disneyland for the global elite. But now that the action has shifted to the human world, the premise has been turned on its head: How much control do humans have over their destinies? It turns out to be far less than they might imagine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Caldwell
title: Sacred Heart Is No Hockey School. $60 Million Could Change That.
description: Under its athletic director, Bobby Valentine, the small Connecticut university is expanding its facilities in the hopes of becoming a college hockey power.
content: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Sacred Heart, a Roman Catholic university tucked in the tidy suburbs along Connecticut’s southern coast, has been around since 1963 and has had a men’s ice hockey program for 27 seasons — including nine straight losing seasons entering this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Bangladesh?
description: Can you find Bangladesh on a map? What else do you know about this South Asian nation with a population of about 165 million people?
content: Can you find Bangladesh on a map? What else do you know about this South Asian nation with a population of about 165 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Lentils, Rice, Caramelized Onions and a Dinner to Remember
description: Adapted from a Middle Eastern mujadara, this streamlined take falls somewhere between a soup and a stew.
content: Today’s pantry dish is a hearty one, built on a solid foundation of lentils and rice topped with golden fried onions. Adapted from a Middle Eastern mujadara, this streamlined version is brothier than the original, somewhere between a soup and a stew. Simmered together in one pot, it’s faster and more flexible, using any kind of lentils, rice and allium you’ve got on hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Having a Baby During the Coronavirus Outbreak?
description: We’d like to hear from expectant parents on how they are coping.
content: People who are delivering soon across America have planned their deliveries weeks or months in advance. But as coronavirus cases surge, many of those plans need to be completely reworked. Some hospitals have taken unprecedented steps like barring partners, relatives and doulas from the delivery room. With shelter-in-place orders, many expecting mothers may not have their safety net of family and friends around for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Quarantine Diaries
description: Around the world, the history of our present moment is taking shape in journal entries and drawings.
content: Before the end of life as we knew it, Ady, an 8-year-old who lives in the Bay Area of San Francisco, read a biography of Anne Frank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan and Tina Jordan
title: Finding Comfort in the Classics
description: Editors and writers on the Books desk — along with colleagues from the newsroom — recommend some time-tested books that offer escape from the present moment.
content: Sometimes you want to blot out the news by picking up the latest thriller or romance novel. At other times, though, the books that give you the most solace are the ones that have stood the test of time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Was Not Designed for Emptiness
description: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.
content: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 914 Dead in N.Y.C., and City’s Virus Case Count Tops 38,000
description: The outbreak’s toll continued to rise amid a hopeful sign: the arrival of a Navy hospital ship to ease the strain on the city’s overwhelmed hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says Pompeo Made It Lose All Interest in Dialogue With U.S.
description: Accusing the secretary of state of slander, the North says he is going against President Trump’s will.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Monday that it had lost all appetite ​for dialogue with the United States because of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s continuous pressure​ on the ​country to give up its nuclear ​weapons program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Nurses Die, Doctors Fall Sick and Panic Rises on Virus Front Lines
description: The pandemic has begun to sweep through New York City’s medical ranks, and anxiety is growing among normally dispassionate medical professionals.
content: A supervisor urged surgeons at Columbia University Irving Medical Center in Manhattan to volunteer for the front lines because half the intensive-care staff had already been sickened by coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Governors Plead for Tests, Trump Promises Ventilators to Europe
description: Maryland, Virginia and Arizona issued statewide stay-at-home orders, and the F.D.A. granted emergency approval for the use of two malaria drugs to treat some coronavirus patients.
content: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Quarantine Diaries
description: Around the world, the history of our present moment is taking shape in journal entries and drawings.
content: Before the end of life as we knew it, Ady, an 8-year-old who lives in the Bay Area of San Francisco, read a biography of Anne Frank.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lentils, Rice, Caramelized Onions and a Dinner to Remember
description: Adapted from a Middle Eastern mujadara, this streamlined take falls somewhere between a soup and a stew.

Adapted from a Middle Eastern mujadara, this streamlined version is brothier than the original, somewhere between a soup and a stew. Simmered together in one pot, it’s faster and more flexible, using any kind of lentils, rice and allium you’ve got on hand.

Some hospitals have taken unprecedented steps like barring partners, relatives and doulas from the delivery room. With shelter-in-place orders, many expecting mothers may not have their safety net of family and friends around for help.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Was Not Designed for Emptiness
description: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.
content: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Are My Obligations if I’m a Doctor Who Is High Risk?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how a physician should balance treating patients against protecting himself during the coronavirus pandemic — and more.
content: I am a physician in an urgent-care setting in the Pacific Northwest, and thus I am at some risk for exposure to coronavirus even when following appropriate precautions. I am in a category that is considered high risk for complications were I to become ill with the coronavirus. The C.D.C. has recommended as of March 8 that individuals at high risk try to limit their public exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Coronavirus, Hospital Ship, van Gogh: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Donate N95 Masks
description: Even a single one is worth offering for donation. But call a health department or look online for drop-off specifics — don’t bring them to a hospital.
content: “Giving a mask to a health care provider on the front line has more potential for a positive impact than wearing it around the grocery store,” says Conrad Amenta, director of policy and strategic initiatives at the California Academy of Family Physicians, which represents some 11,000 family doctors. Many of them have recently said they were running out of supplies and would welcome donations of personal protective equipment, including face shields, surgical gowns, nonlatex gloves, sanitizing gel and especially respirator-type N95 masks. “Please don’t just go walking into a hospital trying to drop them off,” Amenta says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Xinjiang Returns to Work, but Coronavirus Worries Linger in China
description: The Chinese region, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims are held in indoctrination camps, has been an information void. Uighurs fear a lockdown in the region drove many to hunger.
content: HONG KONG — In the Xinjiang region of northwestern China, the government says, major construction projects have resumed, oil field workers are back on the job, garment factories are making masks and spring planting is underway. Students returned to school last week, and one class was greeted by the region’s top Communist Party leader, who wore a mask while speaking to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Just Spent $2 Trillion on Coronavirus Relief. It’s Eyeing More.
description: With the $2 trillion economic stimulus just signed into law on Friday, Washington is already considering a fourth response package to combat the spread of the coronavirus and bolster a shuddering economy.
content: WASHINGTON — As the toll of the coronavirus continues to rise — with more state shutdowns, extensive new layoffs and overwhelmed hospitals — lawmakers and administration officials are turning their focus to what more is needed to counter the pandemic and protect a battered economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: President Trump’s Prime-Time Pandemic
description: The coronavirus briefings have given Donald Trump a regularly scheduled reality show again — or, rather, a create-your-own-reality show.
content: “I’ve gotten to like this room,” President Trump said March 23 in the White House briefing room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib, Sameer Yasir and Rebecca Conway
title: For India’s Laborers, Coronavirus Lockdown Is an Order to Starve
description: Despite leaders’ decrees on staying home, laborers who live hand-to-mouth say they have no choice but to keep hitting the streets. Here are their stories.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has ordered a lockdown of India’s 1.3 billion citizens to fight the spread of coronavirus, urging people to distance themselves socially and work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: What the ‘Cuomo 2020’ Fantasy Says About 2020 Reality
description: Daily briefings during the crisis in New York have given Gov. Andrew Cuomo a captive audience, and a growing fan base. But he has made it clear that he’s not going anywhere.
content: His is a new coalition, couch-bound and spooked, finding small comforts where few had sought sustenance before: in the tender embrace of a disaster briefing by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jesse McKinley
title: N.Y. Hospitals Face $400 Million in Cuts Even as Virus Battle Rages
description: State lawmakers said that slashing hospital budgets to rein in Medicaid costs while the coronavirus is spreading is “cruel, inhumane and unacceptable.”
content: For the last few weeks, Dr. David Perlstein has been scrambling to find more beds and ventilators, knowing that the coronavirus outbreak, which has filled his Bronx hospital with more than 100 patients, will undoubtedly get much worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Alan Merrill, a Songwriter of ‘I Love Rock ’n’ Roll,’ Dies
description: The musician, who died of the coronavirus, had an early rock career in Japan before helping write the song that became Joan Jett’s breakthrough hit.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Pandemic Book Club
description: How to get through this cataclysm even halfway calm: Enter a slower world.
content: NASHVILLE — In a recent Facebook post, Tiffany Lauderdale Phillips described taking a call at her bookstore in Franklin, Ind.: “Wild Geese Bookshop, this is Tiffany.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Alan Merrill, a Songwriter of ‘I Love Rock ’n’ Roll,’ Dies
description: The musician, who died of the coronavirus, had an early rock career in Japan before helping write the song that became Joan Jett’s breakthrough hit.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

description: How to get through this cataclysm even halfway calm: Enter a slower world.
content: NASHVILLE — In a recent Facebook post, Tiffany Lauderdale Phillips described taking a call at her bookstore in Franklin, Ind.: “Wild Geese Bookshop, this is Tiffany.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Keep It Simple, Albany. This Is No Time for Budget Games.
description: Governor Cuomo and state lawmakers should pass a streamlined budget and fight their policy battles another day.
content: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s leadership during the coronavirus pandemic has been disciplined and deft. May he and the Legislature approach this week’s budget negotiations with the same steady focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib, Sameer Yasir and Rebecca Conway
title: For India’s Laborers, Coronavirus Lockdown Is an Order to Starve
description: Despite leaders’ decrees on staying home, laborers who live hand-to-mouth say they have no choice but to keep hitting the streets. Here are their stories.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has ordered a lockdown of India’s 1.3 billion citizens to fight the spread of coronavirus, urging people to distance themselves socially and work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

content: For the last few weeks, Dr. David Perlstein has been scrambling to find more beds and ventilators, knowing that the coronavirus outbreak, which has filled his Bronx hospital with more than 100 patients, will undoubtedly get much worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Social Distancing, Sweden: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 30, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 30, 2020.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Olympians Have Another Year to Prepare for Tokyo. It’s a Blessing and a Curse.’
description: In this lesson, students learn about the reality for athletes who now have another year to train, but also face uncertainty about what that time could do to their health, Olympic potential and finances.
content: Featured Article: “Olympians Have Another Year to Prepare for Tokyo. It’s a Blessing and a Curse” by Juliet Macur, Karen Crouse, Andrew Keh and Matthew Futterman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Emma Goldberg
title: Why Are California and New York Different in the Virus Crisis?
description: Monday: It’s too early to say for sure, but some experts say early action by California leaders has helped. Also: Art during the pandemic.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Short Film of the Day
description: Need a break? Some distraction? Here’s a little something to take you away.
content: We’re stuck at home, obsessing about the news, worrying about our families, worrying about our job situation. We need a break! So every day, our writers will share a short film, a scene, an inexplicable clip that they love. We hope you’ll enjoy it, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Suffering and Scientific Legacy of a Large Family Consumed by Schizophrenia
description: Robert Kolker’s “Hidden Valley Road” is a vividly told story of both a very unfortunate family and a long misunderstood affliction.
content: Donald Galvin was a sophomore at Colorado State when he first checked into the campus health clinic to get treated for a cat bite, offering no further explanation of what had occurred. Two years and several visits later, he arrived at the clinic with another cat bite — only this time he told a doctor what happened to the cat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Emma Goldberg
title: Why Are California and New York Different in the Virus Crisis?
description: Monday: It’s too early to say for sure, but some experts say early action by California leaders has helped. Also: Art during the pandemic.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Minzner
title: Quarantine the Sick in New York’s Hotels
description: Asking the mildly ill to self-isolate at home only endangers other people in their households.
content: New York City today is like Wuhan, the city in central China with the first known Covid-19 outbreak, in late January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Myke Cole
title: Congress Must Pass the Living Artists Act
description: It’s 2046, and the “Estate Craze” is setting the music industry on a dangerous path.
content: Editors’ note: This is part of the Op-Eds From the Future series, in which science fiction authors, futurists, philosophers and scientists write Op-Eds that they imagine we might read five, 10, 50 or even 200 years from now. The challenges they predict are imaginary — for now — but their arguments illuminate the urgent questions of today and prepare us for tomorrow. The Opinion piece below is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Theroux
title: Paul Theroux Recalls a Fear-Filled Lockdown
description: In 1966, the writer was in Uganda at a time of curfew and violence. It shaped his thinking about travel writing’s imperative to bear witness.
content: In this season of infection, the stock market little more than a twitching corpse, in an atmosphere of alarm and despondency, I am reminded of the enlightenments of the strict curfew Uganda endured in 1966. It was, for all its miseries, an episode of life lessons, as well as monotonous moralizing (because most crises enliven bores and provoke sententiousness). I would not have missed it for anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $750,000 Homes in California
description: A 1962 prefabricated beach cottage in Malibu, a Spanish-style house in Fallbrook and a cabin near Lake Tahoe.
content: Centered around an especially lovely stretch of beach in Malibu, Paradise Cove is a gated neighborhood made up of around 250 manufactured homes. Since the 1960s, it has been a popular home base for beach lovers of all stripes — competitive surfers and Academy Award-winners included. The community is tight-knit, and residents regularly hold group cookouts, holiday events and golf-cart parades (the primary mode of transportation in the neighborhood).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alana Newhouse
title: The Power of Passover During a Plague
description: Most Jews in history have not been free, whether from murderous regimes, famines or pandemics like this one. What we have been is devoted to the idea that we deserve to be.
content: This year, Passover falls at the beginning of April — smack in the middle of what some experts estimate will be the peak of the coronavirus pandemic in America. It’s not just the timing of the holiday — built around a retelling of the Jews’ exodus from politicianry in Egypt — that feels off. It’s that every aspect of its story and rituals now seems almost cruelly ironic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Gammon
title: Should You Have a Home Birth Because of Coronavirus?
description: Women are reconsidering their options for delivering babies, but there are not enough midwives to meet their needs.
content: Karla Vitrone is starting to get nervous. Her second baby is due in early June.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Back From the Brink
description: “You always live in fear that you’re never going to wake up.” What one medical professional learned after being the first confirmed coronavirus patient in New Jersey.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Zororo Makamba, 30, Dies; Zimbabwean Television Host
description: His death from the coronavirus was the first to be recorded in his southern African nation.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, Japan’s Economy, Uighurs: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Motoko Rich
title: Summer Olympics in Tokyo to Start on July 23, 2021
description: The new date for the Games, postponed for a year in response to the coronavirus pandemic, gives athletes time to recalibrate their training schedules.
content: After weeks of uncertainty around having the Summer Olympics and when, organizers of the event on Monday provided some clarity: The Games in Tokyo will start July 23, 2021, almost exactly a year later than originally scheduled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher
title: 2 Top Democratic Groups Form Alliance to Support Joe Biden
description: Unite the Country, a super PAC supporting Mr. Biden’s campaign, and the progressive group American Bridge are hoping to raise about $175 million together to defeat President Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Two of the most prominent outside Democratic groups are forming a partnership to pool resources and research to help elect former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. this fall, an attempt at consolidating fund-raising in an increasingly competitive marketplace for third-party organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal and Emmarie Huetteman
title: He Got Tested for Coronavirus. Then Came the Flood of Medical Bills.
description: Hidden costs for E.R. visits and other fees could cost people thousands of dollars.
content: By March 5, Andrew Cencini, a computer science professor at Bennington College, had been having bouts of fever, malaise and a bit of difficulty breathing for a couple of weeks. Just before falling ill, he had traveled to New York City, helped with computers in a local prison and gone out on multiple calls as a volunteer firefighter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Triple Crown Hopeful Emerges and Athlete Workouts Get a J. Lo Cameo
description: Tiz the Law won the Florida Derby, a prep race for the Kentucky Derby, which now isn’t till September. And athletes are creating new ways of practicing on their own, with mixed results.
content: The day in (no) sports includes (some) sports, as horse racing preps for a Triple Crown like no other. Elsewhere, athletes improvised workouts and enlisted workout partners, including a special appearance by J. Lo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: For Shut-In Pilgrims, the World’s Holiest Sites Are a Click Away
description: The pandemic has closed holy sites across the globe, but virtual reality is providing worshipers a digital window into ceremonies during touchstone holidays.
content: For nearly two years, Eilat Lieber, director and chief curator of the Tower of David Museum in Jerusalem’s Old City, has been excited for this April, when Passover, Easter and Ramadan — touchstone holidays of three major  religions — would collide for the first time in nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Trump Won the Internet. Democrats Are Scrambling to Take It Back.
description: In the era of big data, memes and disinformation, the Democrats are trying to regain their digital edge as the president and his loyalists dictate the terms of debate.
content: The deceptively edited video that purported to show Joseph R. Biden Jr. endorsing President Trump’s re-election bounced relentlessly around the internet, falsely painting the former vice president as too confused to know what office he was running for or whom he was vying to run against.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: These Days, Even a Michelin Star Chef Has to Sell Takeout
description: Many restaurants had been planning for a future in which delivery made up a sizable share of their business. They just didn’t expect that moment to arrive right now.
content: For nearly three years, the chef T.J. Steele refused to offer delivery at Claro, his Michelin star restaurant in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan, Andrew Jacobs and Choe Sang-Hun
title: The World Pushes Back Against E-Cigarettes and Juul
description: Facing ire at home, the e-cigarette giant counted on international expansion to offset losses in the U.S., but the regulatory response abroad has been even worse.
content: In January 2019, the chairman of Altria, Howard A. Willard III, flew to Silicon Valley to speak to senior executives of Juul Labs, fresh off signing a deal for the tobacco giant to pay nearly $13 billion for a 35 percent stake in the popular e-cigarette company. With public fury growing over Juul’s contribution to the epidemic of teenage vaping, he laid out his vision for the company to continue to thrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: These Days, Even a Michelin Star Chef Has to Sell Takeout
description: Many restaurants had been planning for a future in which delivery made up a sizable share of their business. They just didn’t expect that moment to arrive right now.
content: For nearly three years, the chef T.J. Steele refused to offer delivery at Claro, his Michelin star restaurant in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Motoko Rich
title: Summer Olympics in Tokyo to Start on July 23, 2021
description: The new date for the Games, postponed for a year in response to the coronavirus pandemic, gives athletes time to recalibrate their training schedules.
content: After weeks of uncertainty around having the Summer Olympics and when, organizers of the event on Monday provided some clarity: The Games in Tokyo will start July 23, 2021, almost exactly a year later than originally scheduled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Greenhouse
title: Is Your Grocery Delivery Worth a Worker’s Life?
description: Workers around the country are walking off the job to protest a lack of protective equipment, safety measures, even soap.
content: Millions of white-collar workers are telecommuting from home to stay safe as the coronavirus extends its terrifying reach across America. But millions of other workers — supermarket cashiers, pharmacists, warehouse workers, bus drivers, meatpacking workers — still have to report to work each day, and many are furious that their employers are not doing enough to protect them against the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher
title: 2 Top Democratic Groups Form Alliance to Support Joe Biden
description: Unite the Country, a super PAC supporting Mr. Biden’s campaign, and the progressive group American Bridge are hoping to raise about $175 million together to defeat President Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Two of the most prominent outside Democratic groups are forming a partnership to pool resources and research to help elect former Vice President Joseph R. source.name: The New York Times

author: By David S. Ludwig and Richard Malley
title: Americans Are Already Too Diseased to Go Back to Work Right Now
description: The huge burden of obesity and other chronic conditions among people in the U.S. puts most of us at direct risk.
content: Public health measures to slow the spread of Covid-19 have already taken a staggering toll on the economy, with the prospect of worse to come. The strategy at the heart of prevention, physical distancing, will continue to be tremendously disruptive to society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Shannon Doyne
title: Has Your School Switched to Remote Learning? How Is It Going So Far?
description: What does a “school day” now look like for you? Are you able to stay on task? Do you have enough work to do — or too much? What do you miss the most about going to school in person every day? What do you miss the least?
content: Has your school shifted to remote learning in response to the global pandemic? How is it going so far?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Trump Backs Off a Promise
description: Social distancing will continue, and all eyes are on New York: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump and Defense Secretary Mark Esper watched the Comfort, a Navy hospital ship, depart Norfolk, Va., for New York City on Saturday to support the city’s response to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: Coronavirus, New York, China: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here's what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in April
description: New additions include Martin Scorsese’s adaptation of “The Age of Innocence” and “Sergio” starring Ana De Armas.
content: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of TV shows and movies to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for April, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Failure of Policy and Planning
description: When the coronavirus crisis required ramping factories to make ventilators, the government’s ability to harness factory capacity crumpled.
content: The goal of “opening up” the U.S. economy by April 12 didn’t last long — social-distancing guidelines have been extended to April 30. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $750,000 in California
description: A 1962 prefabricated beach cottage in Malibu, a Spanish-style house in Fallbrook and a cabin near Lake Tahoe.
content: A 1962 prefabricated beach cottage in Malibu, a Spanish-style house in Fallbrook and a cabin near Lake Tahoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: You Deserve a Good Lunch
description: Step away for half an hour today, if you can, and make yourself a turkey and apple sandwich, an easy pea soup or an omelet, using Jacques Pépin’s technique.
content: Good morning. Here we go again with the screens and the earphones, another day on the uncomfortable chair, the dog at my feet. The commute wasn’t bad, though, and there was a beautiful, orange-yolked egg for breakfast, nestled in a piece of toast — what some call a Guy Kibbee, after the actor, who made the dish in a film — and a tall glass of cold-brewed coffee to go with it. Pretty grand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Can Japan’s Economy Get Any Worse? It May Soon Find Out
description: As the coronavirus has prolonged a deep slump in Japan, one ray of hope has come from its avoidance of a crippling lockdown. But it’s unclear whether that can last.
content: TOKYO — Even before the new coronavirus, Japan’s economy was in trouble. Exports were plummeting on slowing demand from China, and a tax increase at home was keeping shoppers out of stores. The numbers were stark: Economic output contracted 7.1 percent in the last quarter of 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: ‘Live! From the Basement …’
description: Why was Stephen Colbert in a bathtub? Working from home for some jobs requires extra creativity.
content: Savannah Guthrie, a co-anchor of NBC’s “Today” show, broadcasts from the basement of her home in upstate New York. Stephen Colbert drew laughs when he delivered his “The Late Show” monologue from his bathtub; and Jimmy Fallon can be found juggling “The Tonight Show” duties with his two daughters, who scribble his graphics in crayon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Singapore’s Top Court Upholds Law Criminalizing Gay Sex
description: The court declined to strike down a colonial-era law that provides for jail terms of up to two years for a man found to have committed an act of “gross indecency” with another man.
content: SINGAPORE — Singapore’s high court upheld on Monday a rarely used law that criminalizes sex between men, dismissing three appeals that argued it was unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: The Best Movies and Shows on Hulu Right Now
description: We’ve hand-picked the finest movies and television shows currently streaming on Hulu in the United States. Take a look.
content: We’ve hand-picked the finest movies and television shows currently streaming on Hulu in the United States. Take a look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Gunter
title: Coronavirus and Sex: Questions and Answers
description: Some of us are mating in actual captivity. Some of us not at all. The pandemic raises lots of issues around safe intimate physical contact, and what it may look like in the future.
content: These are not sexy times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Penguin Classics and Others Work to Diversify Offerings From the Canon
description: Across the industry, publishers are releasing titles by authors who were previously marginalized or entirely lost to history.
content: When the playwright and filmmaker Kathleen Collins’s short stories were published in 2016, nearly 30 years after her death in 1988, they were called a “revelation.” The stories, deeply moving and autobiographical, had been locked in a trunk untouched for decades, along with a trove of other work, until Collins’s daughter, Nina Lorez Collins, took on the task of bringing them to light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Penguin Classics and Others Work to Diversify Offerings From the Canon
description: Across the industry, publishers are releasing titles by authors who were previously marginalized or entirely lost to history.
content: When the playwright and filmmaker Kathleen Collins’s short stories were published in 2016, nearly 30 years after her death in 1988, they were called a “revelation.” The stories, deeply moving and autobiographical, had been locked in a trunk untouched for decades, along with a trove of other work, until Collins’s daughter, Nina Lorez Collins, took on the task of bringing them to light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: ‘Health Care Kamikazes’: How Spain’s Workers Are Battling Coronavirus, Unprotected
description: Over 12,000 health care workers have contracted Covid-19 in Spain amid grave shortages in personal protective equipment. Nurses and doctors showed us how they make their own gowns, masks and shields.
content: Over 12,000 health care workers have contracted Covid-19 in Spain amid grave shortages in personal protective equipment. Nurses and doctors showed us how they make their own gowns, masks and shields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Serial Killer Known as ‘Grim Sleeper’ Dies in Prison
description: Lonnie D. Franklin Jr., 67, was found unresponsive in his cell at a California prison on Saturday and later pronounced dead, officials said. There were no signs of trauma.
content: A Los Angeles serial killer known as “the Grim Sleeper,” on death row since his conviction for 10 murders in 2016, was pronounced dead on Saturday after being found unresponsive in his prison cell, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Are Democrats Cool on Biden?
description: Republicans are more excited to vote for President Trump than Democrats are for their likely nominee, polling shows.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: 16 Aesthetically Pleasing Puzzles and Games to Play at Home
description: From a pie-shaped jigsaw to an artist-designed chess set, good, analog fun that hones — and frees — the mind.
content: In the 2018 film “Puzzle,” a stifled, suburban Connecticut woman finds unexpected liberation in the world of competitive jigsaw puzzling. “When you complete a puzzle, when you finish it,” her puzzle partner tells her, “you know that you have made all the right choices.” It’s an appealing thought, especially in a time of heightened uncertainty. And you don’t have to go pro to experience that same satisfaction — or the sense of tranquil determination that precedes it, when you are fully focused on the task at hand, and not, say, on a global pandemic. Advocates of puzzles cite their meditative, anxiety-reducing effects; they have also been shown to keep practitioners mentally sharp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: William Helmreich, Sociologist and a Walker in the City, Dies at 74
description: A scholar of Judaism as well, he walked every block in New York — totaling 6,163 miles — and wrote a book about his odyssey. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Bassett, Eric Gonzalez and Darren Walker
title: Andrew Cuomo, Stop a Coronavirus Disaster: Release People From Prison
description: This is a public health crisis that threatens to become a humanitarian disaster.
content: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has been an exemplar of leadership in this time of crisis, someone to whom other state and local officials are looking for guidance. On Friday, the governor took the crucial step of ordering the release of 1,100 people from New York’s jails and prisons. But he must do more. If we don’t act fast, we jeopardize the lives of many. Worse yet, we risk creating a uniquely deadly incubator for the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Number of Coronavirus Deaths in N.Y. Verges on 1,000
description: "Thousands of people will pass away," the governor warned.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Texas Abortion Clinics Can Keep Operating, Judge Rules
description: A Texas order said abortion was a nonessential medical procedure that had to be delayed because of the coronavirus. A federal judge ruled that amounted to a ban on abortion.
content: WASHINGTON — Abortion clinics in Texas can keep operating, a federal judge ruled on Monday, a week after the state’s attorney general said abortion was among the nonessential surgeries and medical procedures that had to be delayed because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Schramm, Blustery Comic Foil in ‘Wings,’ Dies at 73
description: Though known from his TV role, he did much of his work on the stage, starting as an original Acting Company member.
content: David Schramm, an acclaimed stage and television actor best known for his role as the irascible owner of a small airline on the long-running sitcom “Wings” in the 1990s, has died. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Navy Hospital Ship Reaches New York. But It’s Not Made to Contain Coronavirus.
description: Navy officials insist that they are doing everything short of Saran-wrapping the ship to try to keep it virus-free.
content: WASHINGTON — The enormous hospital ship U.S.N.S. Comfort arrived in New York Harbor Monday morning, a gleaming white beacon of hope for a besieged city as it fights the novel coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Schramm, Blustery Comic Foil in ‘Wings,’ Dies at 73
description: Though known from his TV role, he did much of his work on the stage, starting as an original Acting Company member.
content: David Schramm, an acclaimed stage and television actor best known for his role as the irascible owner of a small airline on the long-running sitcom “Wings” in the 1990s, has died. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Listen to the Call: Bullock and Trump Discuss Testing
description: Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana discussed the difficulty of getting access to coronavirus tests on a conference call with President Trump and other governors.
content: Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana discussed the difficulty of getting access to coronavirus tests on a conference call with President Trump and other governors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Maggie Haberman and Mike Baker
title: Trump Suggests Lack of Testing Is No Longer a Problem. Governors Disagree.
description: The president said on a conference call that he had not “heard about testing in weeks.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump told governors on a conference call on Monday that he had not “heard about testing in weeks,” suggesting that a chronic lack of kits to screen people for the coronavirus was no longer a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: U.S. to Announce Rollback of Auto Pollution Rules, a Key Effort to Fight Climate Change
description: The Trump administration has finalized new fuel efficiency standards, lowering expectations from 54 miles per gallon by 2025 to 40 miles a gallon by 2030.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is expected on Tuesday to announce its final rule to rollback Obama-era automobile fuel efficiency standards, relaxing efforts to limit climate-warming tailpipe pollution and virtually undoing the government’s biggest effort to combat climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Human Stories of the Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Some students want to abolish grades; people are working on their “Quarantine Routines”; and, handily, it’s National Doctor’s Day.
content: Perhaps you didn’t think to observe it last year. This year, as the coronavirus pandemic has sickened nearly 800,000 worldwide, people are wholeheartedly making sure they thank a nearby medical professional on National Doctor’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Hospital Safety Rules Are Relaxed to Fight Coronavirus
description: The federal government has redefined a hospital to include tents and dormitory rooms.
content: The federal government announced Monday that it was relaxing many of its usual safety standards for hospitals so they could expand services to fight the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan
title: For Autocrats, and Others, Coronavirus Is a Chance to Grab Even More Power
description: Leaders around the world have passed emergency decrees and legislation expanding their reach during the pandemic. Will they ever relinquish them?
content: LONDON — In Hungary, the prime minister can now rule by decree. In Britain, ministers have what a critic called “eye-watering” power to detain people and close borders. Israel’s prime minister has shut down courts and begun an intrusive surveillance of citizens. Chile has sent the military to public squares once occupied by protesters. Bolivia has postponed elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Lindsey Rogers Cook
title: They Can’t Afford to Quarantine. So They Brave the Subway.
description: Subway use has plummeted in recent weeks, but in poorer areas of New York City, many people are still riding.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic has all but shut down New York City, its subway — an emblem of urban overcrowding — has become almost unrecognizable, with overall ridership down 87 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Celebrity Culture Is Burning
description: The pandemic has disrupted relations among the masses, the elites and the celebrities who liaise between them.
content: America is in crisis, but the celebrities are thriving. They are beaming into our homes, reminding us to stay indoors and “stay positive,” as “we’re all in this together.” When I watch their selfie public service announcements, I find my attention drifting to the edges of the frame: to the understated wall molding visible behind Robert DeNiro’s shoulder; to the Craftsman beams on Priyanka Chopra’s balcony; to the equine wallpaper framing Zoë Kravitz’s crackling fireplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Families Scramble to Find Baby Formula, Diapers and Wipes
description: Panic buying has left stores and diaper banks empty of baby essentials as shutdowns and quarantines expand across the country.
content: Until Catie Weimer’s baby, Arlo, was 4 months old, he would scream and pull his head away from the bottle every time she tried to feed him formula. If she got any of it into him, he’d vomit. He was born at 37 weeks, and she was already worried that he was on the small side when she learned that he had a milk protein allergy and was put on the hypoallergenic formula Alimentum.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stop the Attacks on Anthony Fauci, and Listen to Him
description: Readers urge the country — and President Trump — to heed the infectious-disease expert.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Lindsey Rogers Cook
title: They Can’t Afford to Quarantine. So They Brave the Subway.
description: Subway use has plummeted in recent weeks, but in poorer areas of New York City, many people are still riding.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic has all but shut down New York City, its subway — an emblem of urban overcrowding — has become almost unrecognizable, with overall ridership down 87 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan
title: For Autocrats, and Others, Coronavirus Is a Chance to Grab Even More Power
description: Leaders around the world have passed emergency decrees and legislation expanding their reach during the pandemic. Will they ever relinquish them?
content: LONDON — In Hungary, the prime minister can now rule by decree. In Britain, ministers have what a critic called “eye-watering” power to detain people and close borders. Israel’s prime minister has shut down courts and begun an intrusive surveillance of citizens. Chile has sent the military to public squares once occupied by protesters. Bolivia has postponed elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Hospital Safety Rules Are Relaxed to Fight Coronavirus
description: The federal government has redefined a hospital to include tents and dormitory rooms.
content: The federal government announced Monday that it was relaxing many of its usual safety standards for hospitals so they could expand services to fight the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Celebrity Culture Is Burning
description: The pandemic has disrupted relations among the masses, the elites and the celebrities who liaise between them.
content: America is in crisis, but the celebrities are thriving. They are beaming into our homes, reminding us to stay indoors and “stay positive,” as “we’re all in this together.” When I watch their selfie public service announcements, I find my attention drifting to the edges of the frame: to the understated wall molding visible behind Robert DeNiro’s shoulder; to the Craftsman beams on Priyanka Chopra’s balcony; to the equine wallpaper framing Zoë Kravitz’s crackling fireplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Good Doctor’ and ‘The Schouwendam 12’
description: The medical drama completes its third season. And a Dutch mystery series drops on Acorn TV.
content: THE GOOD DOCTOR 10 p.m. on ABC. In the second part of the season finale, the doctors at San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital continue to respond to the major earthquake that rocked their city. The crisis is testing their ingenuity and pushing their personal issues to the surface. Dr. Shaun Murphy (Freddie Highmore), the protagonist of the series, is still reeling from his latest rejection by Lea (Paige Spara), who cited Shaun’s autism as a reason not to pursue a romantic relationship with him. Undeterred, he revealed in the last episode that he hadn’t lost hope. Lea, who was trapped after the earthquake hit and eventually rescued, overheard Shaun’s comments and responded emotionally. But before they could address them, an aftershock left Shaun stranded with a patient in the flooding basement of a collapsed building.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Crisis Pits Patient Privacy Against Public Need to Know
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 30, 2020.
content: “Public health depends a lot on public trust. If the public feels as though they are being misled or misinformed, their willingness to make sacrifices — in this case social distancing — is reduced.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Patchett
title: Ann Patchett on Why We Need Life-Changing Books Right Now
description: The novelist Ann Patchett doesn’t have children and didn’t read middle-grade books. Then she picked up one by Kate DiCamillo and couldn’t stop until she’d read them all.
content: Here’s how it happened: In early November 2018, Kate DiCamillo came to Nashville while she was on tour for her novel “Louisiana’s Way Home.” It’s the middle book of a trilogy that started with “Raymie Nightingale” and ended last year with “Beverly, Right Here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: adjutant
description: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Museum World’s King of Memes Brings Humor to Lockdown
description: Adam Koszary turned a tiny agricultural museum into a social media sensation. What can the world’s major institutions learn from him?
content: LONDON — On March 18, the Royal Academy of Arts — one of Britain’s grandest art museums, closed because of the coronavirus pandemic — issued a challenge on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Liles
title: Online, Virtual Games Escape the New Reality
description: With their ability to be played online, e-sports are one of the last bastions of competitive sports in a world upended by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: NEWNAN, Ga. — A few blocks from downtown, inside a building with a brick and stucco facade, two men were immersed in an e-sports event, one of the safer competitions remaining in a sporting world upended by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: ‘Group of Local Vigilantes’ Try to Forcibly Quarantine Out-of-Towners, Officials Say
description: A group of residents from an island town in Maine cut down a tree and dragged it into the middle of a road.
content: A group of residents from an island town in Maine cut down a tree and dragged it into the middle of a road in an attempt to forcibly quarantine three roommates they believed could have the new coronavirus after arriving from out of state, law enforcement officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Mary Williams Walsh
title: Scary Times for U.S. Companies Spell Boom for Restructuring Advisers
description: Corporations are saving cash, cutting costs and refinancing debt to manage the economic fallout of the coronavirus. Restructuring and bankruptcy experts are already getting calls.
content: Freedom Mortgage, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, is looking for additional financing as millions of homeowners are expected to stop making mortgage payments. The Cheesecake Factory said this past week it wouldn’t be able to make rent payments on its leases because of lost business. And giant companies from Kraft Heinz to Ford have tapped billions of dollars in credit from banks in preparation for an uncertain future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Best Matzo? It’s Homemade
description: This version may not be kosher for Passover, but it’s delicate, airy and quick to make.
content: Of all the delights of the Seder table — the tender brisket, the golden chicken soup flecked with dill, the wine-drenched charoset rich with apples — commercial, kosher-for-Passover matzo falls pretty low on the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: The Doctor’s Symptoms Weren’t Typical. Was She Sick Enough to Stay Home?
description: On her run, she finished a six-mile loop with no trouble, but she felt a little off: a bit of chest tightness, a headache. Was this coronavirus?
content: “I don’t know what you’re feeling,” the supervising doctor said over the phone, his voice calm and reassuring. “But based on the text you sent me, you shouldn’t go to work.” The 29-year-old woman, an anesthesiology resident in her second year of training, breathed a sigh of relief. “Now,” the training-program director continued, “tell me what’s going on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marvar
title: Stress Baking More Than Usual?
description: Confined to their homes, Americans are kneading dough.
content: As the country shuts down city by city and families are being confined to their homes, one thing’s for sure: Americans are baking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: adjutant
description: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Bogotá’s Cacophony Is Hushed by Virus as Congested Streets Empty Out
description: In normal times, Colombia’s crowded capital reverberates with never-ending noise. But under quarantine, the city was overtaken by an extraordinary sound: silence.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The typical Bogotá morning starts at dawn and quickly becomes an eight million-person roar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Retiring to New York City — and Getting a Roommate
description: A teacher from Maine decided to move to New York. Sharing an apartment was the only way to make it work.
content: Connie Ottmann, a high school English teacher from Maine, had always wanted to live in New York City. And last summer, when she was 66, seemed the right time to do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shefali Luthra, Kaiser Health News
title: Temperature Check: Tracking Fever, a Key Symptom of Coronavirus
description: Taking one’s temperature to look for signs of fever is not as easy as it sounds. For one reporter, the first challenge was finding a thermometer.
content: After I was told I’d been exposed to the novel coronavirus, I tried to follow the best medical advice. I started working from home. I socially isolated. And I “self-monitored” for signs I’d been infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Weeknd’s ‘After Hours’ Earns the Year’s Biggest Debut Week
description: The album had 221 million streams and sold 275,000 copies via a variety of bundles with merchandise and tickets to a tour that may have to be postponed.
content: The Weeknd’s new album, “After Hours,” debuted at the top of the latest Billboard album chart, with the equivalent of 444,000 sales in the United States, according to Nielsen — the biggest opening of the year so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Edward Tarr, Renowned Trumpeter Who Delved Into Past, Dies at 83
description: Mr. Tarr was a scholar, teacher and performer who helped revive the natural trumpet, a sweet-sounding, valveless version of the modern instrument.
content: Edward H. Tarr, a trumpeter and musicologist who became one of the world’s eminent authorities on the instrument, resuscitating long-forgotten repertory and leading the way in historically informed performances of baroque and romantic brass music, died on March 24 in Germany. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi
title: ‘I Didn’t Know Whether to Mourn or to Celebrate’: An Afghan Reporter’s Girlhood Education
description: As a U.S. peace deal with the Taliban unfolds, a Times journalist recalls how a visit to one of Afghanistan’s most progressive rural schools triggered a bittersweet flashback to her own childhood dreams.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: This Fireball Ignored the Solar System’s One-Way Signs
description: A meteoroid that grazed the night sky over Australia in 2017 took a very unusual path away from Earth.
content: It’s not unusual for meteors to illuminate night skies over southwestern Australia’s desolate landscapes. But the fireball of July 7, 2017, was different. For a full minute and a half, it just kept burning and burning and burning. The object carved a trace of light as wide across as Texas, then faded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Joe Diffie, Grammy-Winning Country Music Star, Dies at 61
description: He was known for his ballads and honky-tonk singles, like “Home” and “Pickup Man.” On Friday, he announced that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Joe Diffie, who went from working in oil fields and foundries to becoming one of the most commercially successful country singers of the early and mid-1990s, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: As Russia Braces for Coronavirus, Putin Lets Underlings Take the Heat
description: The Russian leader hates to deliver bad news and wants to distinguish his rule from the turbulent presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin. So he is leaving it to his minions to announce harsh measures.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s propagandist in chief was seconds away from starting his show on state television, a two-and-a-half-hour fiesta of flattery celebrating President Vladimir V. Putin’s coolheaded response to the coronavirus pandemic and Russia’s calm in contrast to the lockdowns and panic gripping Europe and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ford Joins Effort to Make Ventilators
description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Early van Gogh Painting Stolen From Dutch Museum
description: “The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring” was the only thing missing after a heist near Amsterdam. Whoever was behind the theft made the move on the artist’s birthday, knowingly or not.
content: BERLIN — A Vincent van Gogh painting was stolen overnight from a small museum in Laren in the Netherlands, just 20 miles southeast of Amsterdam, on what would have been the artist’s 167th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: With Stars at Home, a Coronavirus Pop Benefit Scales Down
description: Alicia Keys, Mariah Carey, Billie Eilish, Camila Cabello and Sam Smith performed remotely to raise money for organizations helping with Covid-19 relief.
content: The “iHeart Living Room Concert for America,” broadcast Sunday night on Fox TV and the iHeartRadio network, was a downsized, deglamorized pop gala. With the coronavirus pandemic keeping Americans at home, the night that had originally been scheduled for the iHeartRadio Music Awards, now postponed, instead became a benefit show for the food-bank charity Feeding America and the First Responders Children’s Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Joe Diffie, Grammy-Winning Country Music Star, Dies at 61
description: He was known for his ballads and honky-tonk singles, like “Home” and “Pickup Man.” On Friday, he announced that he had tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Joe Diffie, who went from working in oil fields and foundries to becoming one of the most commercially successful country singers of the early and mid-1990s, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: As Russia Braces for Coronavirus, Putin Lets Underlings Take the Heat
description: The Russian leader hates to deliver bad news and wants to distinguish his rule from the turbulent presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin. So he is leaving it to his minions to announce harsh measures.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s propagandist in chief was seconds away from starting his show on state television, a two-and-a-half-hour fiesta of flattery celebrating President Vladimir V. Putin’s coolheaded response to the coronavirus pandemic and Russia’s calm in contrast to the lockdowns and panic gripping Europe and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Veale
title: Philip W. Anderson, Nobel Laureate in Physics, Is Dead at 96
description: His work at Princeton and Bell Labs deepened science’s understanding of magnetism, superconductivity and the structure of matter.
content: Philip W. Anderson, an American physicist whose explorations of electronic behavior in solid materials like glass, crystals and alloys led to a Nobel Prize and deepened science’s understanding of magnetism, superconductivity and the structure of matter, died on Sunday in Princeton, N.J. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ford Joins Effort to Make Ventilators
description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom and Alan Feuer
title: ‘We’re Left for Dead’: Fears of Virus Catastrophe at Rikers Jail
description: Already, 167 inmates and 137 staff members have tested positive at New York City’s jails, including the Rikers complex, which is described as crowded and unsanitary.
content: One inmate used an alcohol pad that a barber had given him after a haircut to sanitize a frequently used Rikers Island jailhouse phone. Another used a sock to hold a phone during a 15-minute call. A third said he and others have used diluted shampoo to disinfect cell bars and table tops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Early van Gogh Painting Stolen From Dutch Museum
description: “The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring” was the only thing missing after a heist near Amsterdam. Whoever was behind the theft made the move on the artist’s birthday, knowingly or not.
content: BERLIN — A Vincent van Gogh painting was stolen overnight from a small museum in Laren in the Netherlands, just 20 miles southeast of Amsterdam, on what would have been the artist’s 167th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: With Stars at Home, a Coronavirus Pop Benefit Scales Down
description: Alicia Keys, Mariah Carey, Billie Eilish, Camila Cabello and Sam Smith performed remotely to raise money for organizations helping with Covid-19 relief.
content: The “iHeart Living Room Concert for America,” broadcast Sunday night on Fox TV and the iHeartRadio network, was a downsized, deglamorized pop gala. With the coronavirus pandemic keeping Americans at home, the night that had originally been scheduled for the iHeartRadio Music Awards, now postponed, instead became a benefit show for the food-bank charity Feeding America and the First Responders Children’s Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Are Bike Lanes Really Safe?
description: I’ve had two recent cycling accidents in which I had the right of way but inattentive drivers cut me off.
content: In just the last eight months, I’ve had two cycling accidents when inattentive drivers made right turns and cut me off. So far I’ve been lucky, escaping with bloody scrapes and a bent bike wheel. But I can’t help wondering how long my luck will last.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s Better for Women to Have a Birth Plan
description: A mother emphasizes the value of preparation, especially now. Also: Comparing virus numbers; evangelicals; a therapist’s story.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Three in four Americans are under instruction to stay home, and federal guidelines will be extended for another month.
content: April may prove to be the cruellest month for Americans in the coronavirus outbreak. With case counts rocketing, new hot spots flaring and hard-hit hospitals maxing out, health experts persuaded President Trump over the weekend to forget any hope of reopening the country by Easter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Virus Soars Among Ultra-Orthodox Jews as Many Flout Israel’s Rules
description: Failure to comply with government restrictions is causing the coronavirus to spread in ultra-Orthodox communities up to eight times faster than elsewhere in Israel.
content: BNEI BRAK, Israel — Ultra-Orthodox Jews failing to comply with government instructions to contain the coronavirus are causing it to spread so quickly that Israeli officials are considering blockading entire communities to protect the wider population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: U.S. Retail Crisis Deepens as Hundreds of Thousands Lose Work
description: Furloughs by Macy’s and Gap will affect the majority of their work forces, and show how the pandemic will devastate many retailers.
content: Macy’s and Gap said on Monday that they planned to furlough much of their work forces, a stark sign of how devastating the coronavirus will be for major retailers and their workers who sell clothing, accessories and other discretionary goods.
source.name: The New York Times
